nodes.text: Teacher test-score value-added (VA) measures capture teacher quality that causally affects students long-term outcomes in adulthood
Claim: Higher teacher VA increases students' probability of attending college
Claim: Higher teacher VA increases students' earnings in adulthood
Evidence (cross-class): A one standard deviation improvement in a teacher's VA in a single grade raises college attendance at age 20 by 0.82 percentage points (mean = 37.2%)

Evidence (cross-class): A one standard deviation improvement in teacher VA in a single grade raises annual earnings at age 28 by about 1.34 percent (baseline estimate), implying a present value gain ~ $7,000 per student (discounted to age 12) and undiscounted lifetime gain ~ $39,000
Claim: Higher teacher VA raises the quality of colleges students attend

Evidence: A one standard deviation improvement in teacher VA raises college-quality index by $299 (1.11 percent) on average and raises probability of attending a high-quality college (above median) by 0.72 percentage points

Method: Linked administrative school district records (grades 3–8, 1989–2009) to US federal tax records (1996–2011), matching ~90% to construct a dataset of ~1.1 million students and 6.8 million student-subject-year observations

Method: Two empirical designs used—(a) cross-class comparisons regressing adult outcomes on leave-year-out teacher VA controlling for rich observables; (b) quasi-experimental cohort-difference design exploiting within-school teacher turnover across adjacent cohorts

Method / Identification: Statistical model and assumptions (Assumption 1 forecast-unbiased VA; Assumption 2 selection on observables for cross-class; Assumption 3 quasi-experimental teacher switching orthogonality), use of leave-year-out VA estimates, teacher fixed effects, class-level controls, and clustered standard errors

Evidence (quasi-experimental): Changes in mean teacher VA across adjacent cohorts within school-grade predict changes in college attendance; a one standard deviation improvement raises college attendance by 0.86 percentage points (s.e. 0.23), similar to cross-class estimate
Claim: Test-score-based VA measures are informative proxies for teachers' long-term impacts (test-score VA correlates with adult outcomes and quasi-experimental evidence supports causality)
Claim / Result: Test-score impacts on subsequent grades fade out rapidly (to ~25% after 3–4 years) but effects 're-emerge' in adulthood as earnings and other long-term outcomes rise

Claim / Result: Heterogeneity — English teacher VA has larger long-term impacts than math VA; impacts are significant across grades 4–8 and net impacts holding future teachers fixed remain substantial because tracking coefficients are small

Policy result: Simulation estimates show replacing a teacher in the bottom 5% of the VA distribution with an average teacher would increase present value of students' lifetime income by roughly $250,000 per classroom accounting for drift (estimates vary: ~$407k if selecting on true VA; ~$185k using 3 years of data)

Limitation: Quasi-experimental estimates for earnings are imprecise due to smaller sample of older cohorts and limited early teacher assignment data; concerns remain about gaming, measurement error, drift, and general equilibrium effects when using VA for personnel policy
